questions.text: A 3-year-old child treated by the Ponseti method for idiopathic clubfoot presents with persistent equinovarus despite excellent brace compliance. The orthopaedic team is planning surgical correction. What is the ideal age range for performing a posteromedial soft-tissue release (PMSTR) in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Age 2 - 5 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR). Once the child has crossed the age of 1-2 years, the soft tissues are no longer that pliable that they can be stretched by plaster alone. Surgery is often required in these children to correct the deformity and this involves releasing the tight structures present on the posteromedial side of the foot (behind the medial malleolus).
  • Posteromedial soft tissue release: Two commonly done procedures for PMSTR are Turco’s release via medial hockey stick or J shaped incision and a modified McKay extended release by a transverse incision
  • The structures cut in PMSTR include:
    • Tibialis posterior
    • FHL
    • FDL and
    • Tendo Achilles (lengthened by tenotomy).
  • Treatment: Most babies with significant congenital talipes equinus varus (CTEV) undergo stretching and strapping, usually supervised by a physiotherapist. Alternative methods include serial casts or splints (Dennis Brown splint).
  • Summary (Rx of CTEV):
    • Birth to 1 year- Corrective manipulation
    • 2-3 years - Soft tissue release
    • 4-8 years-Dilwyn evans operation/ Dwayer's osteotomy
    • 8-11 years- wedge tarsectomy
    • >12 years-Triple arthrodesis

questions.text: Obese 10 years old boy c/o of right knee pain and shortening. no hx of fever or trauma on exam patient keeping his leg on external rotation. Dx?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In this condition, the upper femoral epiphysis may get displaced at the growth plate, usually postero-medially, resulting in coxa vara.
  • It occurs more commonly in fat and sexually underdeveloped; or tall, thin sexually normal children.
  • Age: It occurs at puberty (between 12-14 years).
  • Sex: It is commoner in boys.
  • Side: It occurs on both sides in 30 per cent of cases.
  • Presenting symptoms: Pain in the groin, often radiating to the thigh and the knee is the common presenting complaint
  • Trethowan sign is positive in SCFE
  • Treatment of an acute slip: This is by closed reduction and pinning,
  • Treatment of a gradual slip: This depends upon the severity of the slip present.
    • If it is less than 1/3 the diameter of the femoral neck, the epiphysis is fixed internally in situ.
    • If the slip is more than 1/3, a corrective osteotomy is performed at the inter-trochanteric region.

Explanation of Other Options:

AVN (Option A): Avascular necrosis of the femoral head presents more insidiously in older children or adolescents with hip pain, not acute external rotation and limb shortening in an obese preadolescent.

Iliotibial band syndrome (Option C): Overuse injury causing lateral knee pain in active runners; there is no limb shortening or hip rotation deformity.

Osgood schlatte (Option D): Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle with localized anterior knee pain and a raised tibial tubercle, without hip rotation abnormalities or limb length discrepancy.

questions.text: True about Blount disease:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Blount's disease is a growth disorder of the proximal posteromedial tibial epiphysis, leading to pathological tibia vara in early childhood
  • BLOUNT'S DISEASE
    • Disease caused by abnormality of proximal posteromedial tibial epiphysis
    • Classically seen in African-American obese male child (first 3 years) and in west Indies
    • Presents as pathologic tibia vara (bowed legs)
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by drawing metaphyseodiaphyseal angle of Drenan, which if more than 11°, confirms the diagnosis.
  • Treatment- Generally a proximal tibial osteotomy is performed for correction of deformity.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is referred for evaluation of a bowed right leg present since birth. On examination, there is anterolateral bowing of the tibia and cafe-au-lait spots on the trunk. Radiographs demonstrate cortical thinning, cystic changes in the proximal tibia, and no evidence of healing after minor trauma. Which condition is most closely associated with anterolateral tibial bowing in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

\
  • Congenital pseudarthrosis of the tibia: A birth defect in the lower third of the tibia in children, whereby a fracture in this region fails to unite.
  • It is a congenital condition characterized by bowing of tibia (mostly anterolateral bowing).
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 is found in 50-55 % of patients with congenital pseudoarthrosis (while 10% of patients with neurofibromatosis have pseudoarthrosis).
  • It is equally distributed in boys and girls and is almost always unilateral.
  • There is little tendency for the lesion to regress, and the bone eventually fractures through the weakened area.
  • Treatment: Before a fracture occurs, a total contact orthosis is prescribed as prophylaxis. But once a fracture occurs. surgery is indicated.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Calcaneovalgus foot deformity (Option A): A positional foot variant seen in neonates from intrauterine positioning, not linked to tibial bowing.
  • Fibular hemimelia (Option C): Characterised by partial or complete absence of the fibula with associated limb-length discrepancy, not anterolateral tibial bowing.
  • Congenital talipes equinovarus (Option D): Clubfoot deformity of the hindfoot, unrelated to tibial shaft morphology.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presents with 9 month old fracture of the middle right tibia which was being treated by a local bone setter. However the boy still has pain and is unable to walk. X ray shows nonunion with abundant callus formation. Best treatment is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Abundant callus indicates a hypertrophic nonunion, where biological healing potential is intact but mechanical stability is lacking.
  • As there is no union for the last 9 months, we can call this a nonunion.
  • Depending on the amount of callus formation, the nonunion can be
    • Hypertrophic nonunion - abundant callus formation.
    • Atrophic nonunion - very little or no callus formation.
  • Hypertrophic nonunion occurs due to lack of stability at the fracture site. Hence, it can be easily treated by fixing the bone.
  • Atrophic nonunion occurs due to the poor quality of bone in the fracture ends. Hence, they require fixation along with bone grafting for fracture union.

Explanation of Other Options:

Bone grafting (Option B) is primarily indicated in atrophic nonunion with poor biological activity, not in hypertrophic nonunion.

Ilizarov external fixator (Option C) is effective for nonunions but overly complex when simple internal fixation suffices for stability.

BMP injection (Option D): Bone morphogenetic proteins enhance osteogenesis and are reserved for cases with deficient biology, not for stability-driven hypertrophic nonunion.

questions.text: A 19 year old boy involved in a bike accident is brought to the emergency department. He is unconscious, has a flail chest and a type III open femur fracture with femoral artery injury. First step to be done is.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Whenever we approach a patient with serious injury after RTA, we have to follow the ATLS protocol.
  • In the ATLS primary survey, securing the airway (with cervical spine protection) is the first priority especially in an unconscious patient who cannot protect their own airway.
  • Flail chest compromises ventilation, but without a patent airway, even adequate ventilation and perfusion cannot be ensured.
  • Once the airway is secured, breathing (chest tube for flail segment) and circulation (IV fluids and hemorrhage control) can be addressed in sequence.

Explanation of Other Options:

Start IV fluids (Option A): While critical for shock management, circulation is addressed after airway and breathing per the ATLS "A → B → C" sequence.

Put a chest tube (Option B): Chest decompression corrects breathing defects, but cannot occur before ensuring a secure airway in an unconscious patient.

Clamp femoral artery with bulldog clamps (Option D): Hemorrhage control is part of the circulation step and follows airway and breathing interventions.

questions.text: A 75 year old male presents with fracture neck of femur. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In elderly patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, hemiarthroplasty reliably restores mobility and reduces the risk of nonunion or avascular necrosis compared to internal fixation.
  • It allows early weight-bearing and rehabilitation, which is critical to minimize complications (e.g., pneumonia, thromboembolism) in this age group.
  • Compared to total hip replacement, hemiarthroplasty is a shorter procedure with less soft-tissue disruption and lower dislocation rates, making it preferable for lower-demand patients.
  • The treatment protocol for fracture neck of femur is given below.

Explanation of Other Options:

Screw fixation (Option B): Best suited for non-displaced or valgus-impacted femoral neck fractures in younger patients; high failure rates in displaced fractures of the elderly.

McMurray osteotomy (Option C): A salvage procedure for malunited or nonunion fractures, not indicated for acute displaced fractures.

Total hip replacement (Option D): Offers better functional outcomes in active elderly but carries higher operative time, blood loss, and dislocation risk; reserved for patients with preexisting hip arthritis or higher functional demands.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with fracture neck of femur. X ray also shows severe osteoarthritis of the hip joint. What is the ideal treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Total hip replacement (THR) addresses both the acute femoral neck fracture and underlying arthritic joint, providing definitive pain relief and durable function.
  • THR permits immediate full weight-bearing and rehabilitation, reducing risks of immobility-related complications in older adults.
  • Compared to hemiarthroplasty which leaves an arthritic acetabulum untreated. THR avoids persistent groin pain and acetabular cartilage wear.
  • The treatment protocol for fracture neck of femur is given below.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hemiarthroplasty (Option A): Replaces only the femoral head, leaving the arthritic acetabulum intact, often resulting in ongoing pain and acetabular erosion.

Screw fixation (Option B): Suitable for non-displaced fractures in younger patients without arthritis; high rates of nonunion and avascular necrosis in displaced, arthritic hips.

McMurray osteotomy (Option C): A salvage osteotomy for malunions or established nonunions; not indicated for acute displaced fractures with coexistent osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presents with fracture neck of femur after a RTA. What is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In patients younger than 65 years with femoral neck fractures, internal fixation with cannulated screws preserves the native hip, maintains bone stock, and supports high functional demands.
  • These screws are placed in a three-point inverted-triangle configuration to maximize rotational and axial stability, allowing early weight-bearing and reducing the risk of nonunion.
  • Common implant systems include the Synthes Cannulated Screw System or Asnis II cannulated screws, which provide reliable fixation with minimal soft-tissue disruption.
  • Accurate reduction and stable fixation allow early mobilization and carry acceptable rates of union; the risk of avascular necrosis is balanced against the long-term downsides of arthroplasty in younger patients.
  • Screw fixation is less invasive than arthroplasty, has shorter operative time, and avoids prosthesis-related complications.

questions.text: Which displacement is seen in the proximal fragment in proximal third fractures of femur?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The iliopsoas muscle, inserting on the lesser trochanter, flexes the proximal fragment; the gluteus medius, attaching to the greater trochanter, abducts it; and the short lateral rotators impart external rotation, producing the characteristic deformity.
  • Displacement seen in the proximal third fractures of femur is flexion, abduction and external rotation
  • The proximal fragment will be under the following forces
    • Iliopsoas muscle attached to the lesser trochanter - causes flexion
    • Gluteus medius attached to the greater trochanter - causes abduction
    • Short lateral rotators - causes external rotation.

questions.text: What is Hoffa's fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A Hoffa fracture is an intra-articular break through the posterior aspect of a femoral condyle in the coronal plane, most commonly affecting the lateral condyle under axial load with the knee flexed.
  • These fractures are unstable and often occult on standard AP radiographs; CT imaging is recommended for accurate detection and preoperative planning.
  • Definitive management requires open reduction and rigid internal fixation to restore articular congruity, prevent displacement, and reduce the risk of post-traumatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 35 year old alcoholic male was admitted 48 hours back with fracture shaft of femur. He was planned for intramedullary nailing today, but he suddenly developed aggressive and altered behavior. O/E there is tachypnea and petechial rashes in the axilla. The probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Altered behavior after 48 hours can be seen in both alcohol withdrawal and fat embolism syndrome. However the triad of CNS symptoms (altered behavior), respiratory symptoms (tachypnea) and rashes is pathognomonic of fat embolism.
  • Fat embolism syndrome
    • It is a systemic disorder characterized by organ damage due to fat particles in micro circulation.
    • Causes
      1. Trauma (90%) - # Shaft of Femur , # Tibia
      2. Surgeries
        • Joint reconstruction surgeries
        • Liposuction
      3. Diseases
        • Diabetes
        • Acute pancreatitis
        • Sickle cell disease
      4. Burns
    • There is always a 24- 72 hour time delay in the onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man twists his ankle playing basketball and is unable to bear weight afterward. He has tenderness around the malleolar zone. According to the Ottawa ankle rules, which of the following findings would not indicate the need for ankle radiographs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ottawa rules are used for deciding when to take x rays in ankle injuries.
  • The Ottawa ankle rules require ankle X-rays when a patient with pain in the malleolar zone has any one of the following:
    1. Bone tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the lateral malleolus (Option A)
    2. Bone tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the medial malleolus (Option B)
    3. Inability to bear weight both immediately post-injury and for four steps in the ED (Option C)
  • When indicated, radiographs should include three views (anteroposterior, lateral, and 30° mortise) to fully assess the tibiotalar joint.
  • Correct use of the Ottawa rules reduces unnecessary X-rays by up to 30-40%, lowering patient radiation exposure and healthcare costs without compromising fracture detection.
  • Bone tenderness at the navicular bone (Option D) Lies outside the malleolar zone and does not by itself justify ankle radiographs.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ottawa ankle rules streamline imaging: pain in the malleolar zone + any one of three criteria warrants ankle films.
  • Adherence to these rules safely rules out fractures and minimizes unnecessary imaging.

questions.text: Match the implants in Column A with their indications in Column B and select the correct matching set.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Locking Compression Plate (LCP) (1-D) is designed to stabilize intra-articular and peri-articular fractures by providing fixed-angle support when conventional plating may fail.
  • Intramedullary Interlocking Nail (2-E) is the gold standard for femoral and tibial shaft fractures, offering load sharing and early mobilization through locked proximal and distal fixation.
  • Philos Plate (3-C) is contoured for the proximal humerus, allowing angular stability in osteoporotic or comminuted shoulder fractures.
  • Herbert Screw (4-B) is a headless, cannulated compression screw ideal for scaphoid fractures, achieving interfragmentary compression without protruding hardware.
  • Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS) (5-A) converts shear into compression across the fracture site, making it the implant of choice for intertrochanteric hip fractures.
